metadata./Title: SELENON-related myopathy as a cause of acute respiratory failure in middle age: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background SELENON-related myopathy is a rare autosomal recessive congenital neuromuscular disorder linked 
to defects in the selenoprotein N. The clinical onset typically occurs in infancy and axial weakness, rigid spine, and respiratory involvement are almost invariably present at early stages.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We report the case of a 44-year-old Italian woman who underwent intubation for acute respiratory failure, followed by weaning from invasive ventilation within 6 months. Her medical history was not significant, 
but a detailed medical history collection revealed slight motor limitations since childhood such as slow running, difficulty climbing high steps, early muscle exhaustion, and fatigue.
The neurological examination showed a waddling gait and axial and proximal limb muscle weakness without rigid 
spine. The right quadriceps muscle biopsy showed nonspecific myopathic abnormalities. Clinical exome sequencing 
revealed the presence of the two heterozygous variants c.713DupA and c.803G > A in the SELENON gene.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion This report focused on the clinical heterogeneity of SELENON-related myopathy. While we highlight 
that the absence of spinal rigidity and core pathology on muscle biopsy should not exclude the diagnostic suspicion, 
overall we stress the importance of respiratory failure as a possible late manifestation of the disease, even in middleaged individuals.
Keywords  Selenoprotein N-related myopathy, SELENON, Congenital myopathies, Case report
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
SELENON -related myopathy (SELENON -RM) is a rare 
autosomal recessive congenital myopathy associated with 
defects in the SELENON  gene, encoding selenoprotein N, 
a transmembrane protein localized in the sarcoplasmic 
reticulum [1–7]. It acts as a sensor of calcium fluctua tions within the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and helps 
regulate cellular calcium levels, playing a role against 
oxidative damage and ER stress [8]. Furthermore, in 
mouse models, it has recently been shown to be involved 
in mitochondrial integrity and in the calcium transfer 
between organelles [8].Open Access

The exact global prevalence of this condition is 
unknown and is likely underdiagnosed. A recent com prehensive French case series [4] identified 69 cases, with 
an estimated prevalence of 1.03 per million. An earlier 
UK population study of congenital muscular dystrophies 
(CMDs) [9], which included the SEPN1  gene according 
to an old classification [3], found a frequency of 10% (44 
cases out of 440 considered); considering a point preva lence of 0.9 per 100,000 for all CMDs in Northern Eng land, the rarity of SEPN1 -RM within them is evident. 
Lower frequencies were observed in a similar population 
study in Italy (6.25% of 336 cases for SEPN1 -RM, with a 
global prevalence of 0.56 per 100,000 for CMDs) [10].
The age of onset is within the first 2 years of life in 
almost 80% of cases; muscle weakness typically affects 
primarily the neck and trunk axial muscles, and it is asso ciated with early onset rigid spine [3–5]. Respiratory fail ure sets in before adulthood, and people usually require 
nighttime noninvasive ventilation while still being ambu latory [3–5].
However, some cases with atypical phenotypes and 
later onset have been described in the literature, the diag nosis of which is often challenging [3–5]. We here report 
the clinical and molecular findings of an adult female 
patient presenting with acute respiratory failure in mid dle age and harboring compound heterozygote mutations 
in the SELENON  gene.
Case report
First clinical evaluation
A 44-year-old Italian woman experienced an episode of 
acute respiratory failure with respiratory acidosis, not 
owing to impaired gas exchange caused by damaged 
lung parenchyma (pneumonia, acute respiratory distress 
syndrome (ARDS), emphysema, and similar conditions 
were excluded by instrumental and laboratory analysis), 
requiring admission to the intensive care unit and inva sive ventilation via tracheostomy. A total of 4 months 
later, she was switched to noninvasive ventilation, and 
6 months later, the tracheostomy was removed.
The patient was addressed on the suspicion of a muscu lar origin of the respiratory failure.
Her medical history was positive only for hypertension. 
However, a more detailed examination revealed the pres ence of some motor limitations that had “always been 
there, ” such as slow running, difficulty climbing high 
steps, early muscle exhaustion, and fatigue. However, 
throughout her life she had not experienced any signifi cant motor limitations in daily activities, nor any com plaints that could be attributed to sleep hypoventilation 
or apnea (such as morning headache or daytime sleepi ness), and did not think that she “might have an illness. ” No myoglobinuria was reported and her family history 
was negative for neurological diseases.
Neurological examination revealed a waddling gait, 
possible on the toes and more difficult on the heels. The 
squatting maneuver was only hinted at, and the sub sequent return to a standing position was not possible 
without support. She was unable to stand up after sitting 
on the floor.
No bulbar signs, such as difficulties with speech pro duction and swallowing (for example, dysarthria, dys phonia, or dysphagia), were detected. In the upper 
extremities, she had weakness in arm abduction (Medi cal Research Council Scale (MRC) 4/5 bilaterally). In the 
lower limbs, she had weakness in thigh flexion, extension, 
and abduction (MRC 4/5 bilaterally) and in leg flexion 
(MRC 4/5 bilaterally). Slight weakness was also noted in 
the head flexion (MRC 4/5); in the supine position, vol untary head flexion on the trunk was not possible.
Discrete muscular hypotrophy was detected in the 
distal segments of the four limbs. Mild hypotonia of the 
upper limbs was present. Mild right-wing scapula, mild 
lumbar hyperlordosis, and right convex dorsal scoliosis 
were noted. There was no evidence of a rigid spine.
No superficial or deep sensitivity impairment was 
reported. Deep tendon reflexes were present and sym metrical in all limbs. Cerebellar function was normal.
Blood tests revealed creatine kinase (CK) at 310 UI/L 
(normal value < 200) and lactic acid 5.80 mmol/L (normal 
range value 0.5–2.2). The acid alpha-glucosidase assay on 
dried-blood spot (DBS) revealed normal range values.
The electromyography (EMG) findings revealed myo genic signs in all the muscles studied (tibialis anterior, 
biceps brachii, deltoid, first dorsal interosseus, trape zius, and subspinous) and depletion of activated motor 
units in the gluteal musculature. The electroneurography 
(ENG) findings were normal.
At the right quadriceps muscle biopsy, some fascicles 
show fibers with internal nuclei, scattered atrophic fibers, 
and rare degenerated fibers; minimal focal endomisial 
fibrosis was also observed (Fig.  1). Immunohistochemis try with antibodies against dystrophin, alpha-sarcoglycan, 
gamma-sarcoglycan, beta-sarcoglycan, delta-sarcoglycan, 
caveolin-3, dysferlin, alpha-dextroglycan, merosin, colla gen IV, collagen VI, and telethonin was normal.
Next-generation sequencing (NGS) analysis was also 
conducted with a gene panel for myopathy (ANO5, BVES , 
CAPN3 , C AV3 , COL6A1, COL6A2, COL6A3, DAG1 , 
DES, DMD, DNAJB6, DPM3, DYSF , EMD, FHL1, FKRP , 
FKTN , GAA , GMPPB, HNRNPDL, ISPD , KBTBD13, 
LAMA2, LIMS2, LMNA, MYOT , PLEC , POGLUT1, 
POMGNT1, POMGNT2, POMT1 , POMT2 , PTRF, 
PYROXD1, SGCA  , SGCB , SGCD , SGCG  , SMCHD1, 
SYNE1 , SYNE2 , TCAP , TMEM43, TNPO3, TOR1AIP1,

TRAPPC11, TRIM32, TTN , and VCP ) and identified 
three variants of uncertain significance in the PLEC  gene. 
Familial segregation analysis did not confirm their patho genetic role because they were also found in her clinically 
unaffected sister.
Follow‑up evaluation
In the following years, the patient was lost to follow-up 
and was seen again in the outpatient clinic only at the age 
of 53 years, approximately 10 years after the onset of res piratory symptoms.
At this time, the clinical examination showed waddling 
walking and difficulty to go on the heels; it was impos sible for her to get up from the sitting position on the 
ground without help; weakness of the proximal segments 
of upper and lower limbs but also of the hands, feet, and 
axial musculature; hypotrophy of the muscles of the distal 
segments of the four limbs; modest winged right scapula; 
moderate lumbar hyperlordosis and right-convex dorsal 
scoliosis; no rigid spine; severe orthopnea present after a 
few seconds; and moderate dyspnea after efforts during 
the examination.Since the onset of symptoms, the patient regularly used 
noninvasive ventilation (NIV) at night and for about 3 
hours during the day, as well as cough assistance twice 
a day. On reassessment,  CO2 levels were found to be 
within normal limits at night (44.93  mmHg) and per sistently high during spontaneous breathing during 
the day  (PaCO2 50.7  mmHg); ventilation time was then 
increased. At spirometry, forced vital capacity (FVC) was 
1.44 L (47%) in the upper position and 0.74 L (24%) in the 
supine position.
Cardiological examination and cardiac ultrasound did 
not show structural heart disease, while a minimal pul monary hypertensive state was observed.
Muscle imaging could not be performed because the 
severe orthopnea did not make a magnetic resonance 
imaging (MRI) examination feasible.
For further diagnostic purposes, we performed a 
clinical exome sequencing that revealed the pres ence of the heterozygote variants c.713DupA in exon 
5 and c.803G > A in exon 6 of the SELENON  gene 
(NM_020451.3).
The c.713DupA variant (p.Asn238Lysfs) causes a 
frameshift and is predicted to lead to a premature stop

codon at position 63, resulting in a predicted truncated, 
nonfunctional protein. It is classified as pathogenic 
(Clinvar) and indicated as a founder mutation in West ern Europe [4]. It has also been described in two patients 
with multiminicore disease and early severe axial weak ness, scoliosis, and respiratory failure [11].
The c.803G > A variant determines the p.Arg268His 
amino acid substitution and is considered “diseasecausing” by prediction software (Mutation Taster) 
and of uncertain clinical significance according to 
American College of Medical Genetics guidelines 
(PM2 + PM5 + PP3). It has already been described in 
association with SELENON -related myopathic forms [4].
Familial segregation analysis revealed the presence of 
the c.713DupA variant in the asymptomatic proband’s 
mother (aged 79 years) and sister (aged 50 years), whereas 
the c.803G > A variant was found in the asymptomatic 
father (aged 81  years). An asymptomatic proband’s 
brother (51 years old) was not found to be a carrier of any 
variant.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Biallelic mutations in the SELENON  gene have been asso ciated with a number of autosomal recessive disorders 
(congenital myopathy 3 with rigid spine, multiminicore 
myopathy, congenital fiber type dysproportion, SEPN1 related congenital muscular dystrophy, and desminrelated myopathy with Mallory body-like inclusions), 
which despite phenotypic and histological heterogeneity, 
share certain clinical and molecular features and were 
then recognized as the same disease termed “SEPN1 related myopathy” (SEPN1 -RM), and more recently, 
“SELENON -related myopathy” (SELENON -RM)  [4, 12, 
13]. SELENON -RM is now defined as a rare congenital 
neuromuscular condition mainly characterized by early 
onset rigidity of the spine, scoliosis, slowly progressive 
axial muscle weakness, and respiratory insufficiency [12, 
13]. The most severe forms of SELENON -RM occur in 
the first months of life, but cases diagnosed in the second 
to fourth decade of life have also been described in the 
literature [4, 14].
In the study of Villar-Quiles et  al., the first clinical 
signs arose before the age of 15 years in all the patients, 
and clinical onset was more frequent within the age of 
2 years, accounting for 84.7% of the cases [4]. Delayed 
motor development (81.4%), poor head control (57.7%), 
and neonatal hypotonia (33%) were among the most 
common onset symptoms, even though some atypi cal features were reported, for example, predominant 
fatigue, poor sport performance, bulbar dysfunction 
with nasal voice, and ophthalmoplegia [4, 14]. Although 
more common in the axial and limb proximal segments, 
some degree of muscle weakness is usually observed in the distal segments of the four limbs [4]. Notably, axial 
muscles are usually severely involved, and the presence 
of weakness and contractures of the neck extensor and 
dorsal paraspinal muscles leads to a rigid spine [4]. This 
condition is particularly evident at the dorsal level, with 
relative sparing of the lumbar segments, and it is usu ally accompanied by other skeletal abnormalities, such as 
scoliosis with severe lateral trunk shift (requiring com pressive bracing and, often, arthrodesis), dorsal hyperlordosis (resulting in pseudo-scapular wing), and reduced 
anteroposterior thorax diameter due to pectoralis major 
and intercostal muscle retractions [4]. The average age 
of onset of scoliosis is 10 years [4, 14]. Other features of 
this peculiar axial involvement include a typically long, 
slender neck and amyotrophy of the sternocleidomastoid, 
deltoid, and medial thigh muscles [4]. The predominant 
axial involvement is well recognizable on imaging, with 
full-body MRI showing a highly homogeneous muscle 
pattern characterized by atrophy and signal abnormali ties in sternocleidomastoid muscle, paraspinal muscles, 
gluteus maximus, and thigh muscles (semimembranosus, 
sartorius, adductor magnus, and short head of the biceps 
femoris) [15, 16].
A second characteristic feature of the SELENON -RM 
phenotype is restrictive respiratory muscle failure, which 
is typically “disproportionate” to the involvement of the 
remaining skeletal musculature and usually occurs when 
ambulation is still preserved [4, 17]. Respiratory involve ment is due to weakness of the diaphragm, evidenced by 
a decrease in FVC values of more than 10% when moving 
from a sitting to a supine position and gradually leading 
to the inability to lie down [4, 17, 18]. This
sections.Results:
results in early 
orthopnea, unlike other neuromuscular diseases that 
involve premature, fixed intercostal muscle involvement 
(such as spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) [19]), or exer tional dyspnea (such as myasthenia gravis). In the cohort 
of Villar-Quiles RN et  al., respiratory involvement was 
described in 94% of cases and detected within 15 years in 
90.3% [4]. Cardiac abnormalities were noted in 15% of the 
patients, and pulmonary hypertension, which includes 
right ventricular dysfunction owing to pulmonary fail ure, was commonly observed [12]. It has also been rec ognized that extra-muscular involvement can occur, such 
as weight gain, fat tissue accumulation, and mental dis ability [5]. A more recent cross-sectional study confirmed 
axial and limb muscle weakness (proximal more than 
distal), joint contractures, severe diaphragm atrophy and 
dysfunction, fatigue, and pain mostly in the back, neck, 
or shoulders as main features [13]. According to the lit erature, after a slight improvement during adolescence, 
mainly owing to orthopedic treatment and scoliosis 
surgery, the disease slowly progresses in the fourth dec ade of life [4]. Almost all patients achieved independent 
Page 5 of 6
 Risi et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports           (2025) 19:64 
 
walking with stabilization and sometimes improvement 
of motor function in the first two decades of life. This 
phase is usually followed by a slow worsening from the 
third decade onward, leading to a loss of walking ability 
in 10% of cases. More severe progression to tetraparesis 
by the third decade occurs in a few cases [1, 4]. Respira tory impairment seems to be the main limiting prognos tic factor, with death due to respiratory failure in most 
cases, followed by aging and swallowing difficulties [4]. 
Noninvasive ventilation appears to stabilize the decline in 
respiratory muscle strength and may be decisive for the 
prognosis [17, 20].
Histopathologically, multiminicores (small focal areas 
depleted of mitochondria and disorganized sarcomeres, 
reflecting a mitochondrial dysfunction) are reported in 
many cases inconspicuously associated with dystrophic 
signs, but some patients present with nonspecific myo pathic signs, including changes in fibral diameter, inter nalization of nuclei, and prevalent atrophy of type II 
fibers [4].
Compared with the main clinical and histopathological 
findings described in the literature, our case is notewor thy because: (i) although easy muscular exhaustion and 
fatigability were reported since adolescence, no muscu lar disease was suspected until acute respiratory distress 
appeared; (ii) respiratory involvement occurred unusu ally late in the fourth decade; (iii) no rigid spine, which 
usually becomes evident before diaphragmatic involve ment, was observed [13, 20]; and (iv) nonspecific myo pathic signs without core pathology were detected on 
muscle biopsy.
Of note, the very late appearance of respiratory failure 
is quite atypical. There are only some reports of delayed 
respiratory insufficiency with onset in the third decade 
[5, 11], while only one case of acute respiratory insuffi ciency has been described with onset at 71 years of age, 
the oldest age recorded for onset of the condition [21]. 
We do not have definitive explanations for this observa tion. A correlation between body mass index (BMI) and 
motor skills has been observed in literature [4], with 
underweight patients usually showing better perfor mance. The increased adiposity seen in the most severe 
cases may be caused by susceptibility to insulin resistance 
and higher toxicity of saturated fatty acids induced by 
SEPN1  depletion [22]. Our patient’s BMI was 19.5 kg/m2, 
with weight remaining essentially stable over the years. 
Beyond the underlying pathophysiological implications, 
this finding in our case of late-onset disease appears to 
be consistent with previous reports. From a genetic point 
of view, our patient carried a frameshift and a missense 
variant. According to the literature, homozygous or com pound heterozygous variants predicting the absence 
of the protein, regardless of the exon in which they are located, are associated with more severe phenotypes [4]. 
In our case, the concomitance of a truncating mutation 
and a missense mutation could explain the late-onset res piratory involvement and not-too-severe clinical picture.
Conclusion
This case highlights that SELENON -RM should be con sidered a differential diagnosis in adult patients with 
delayed neuromuscular respiratory distress. Greater 
awareness of this condition may lead to earlier diagno sis and more appropriate treatment, given the dispro portionate diaphragmatic involvement in such patients, 
while also considering possible future treatment options, 
such as ER stress-inhibitor therapy [6].
